summary:
I am a Lead Data Platform Engineer with a vast range of domain knowledge (healthcare, research, IT, media, and finance). In my current role, I hold HR responsibilities, I own technical and architectural decisions for the team, and I do hands-on work. The platforms we work with are cloud-based and include Azure, AWS, Databricks, and Snowflake. 

In the past, I have had experience in every other side of data analytics (e.g. ML, BI reporting, dashboarding, ETL, EDA, data modeling, statistics, data quality). 

In terms of team vision, I put a lot of effort into building a positive and nurturing environment for all of us on the team to feel safe and grow together while showing respect to the other teams. I believe a team's well-being is its primary asset, not only because it is in general a good thing, but also considering it is fundamental to maximize productivity and contain turnover. Coherently with this view, I consider part of my role as being the first line of defense for the team, in case of external pressures or general challenges.  

On the strategic side, I have a strong propensity for streamlining both architectures and processes, in order to minimize the time needed for maintenance and give more space to the engineers for more interesting kinds of work. I also focus on accurate and efficient communication, which I tackle by writing rich but pragmatic documentation, and organizing a reasonable amount of frontal meetings.

- Experimental design
- Stimuli presentation
- Sequence choice for acquisitions 
- Data preprocessing
- Statistical analysis
- Data interpretation

This gave me the opportunity to understand which are the issues that one can find during Neuroimaging research and improve my problem solving skills.

Moreover, working in an heterogeneous team (technicians, MDs, psychologysts, engineers) gave me the opportunity to improve my communication skills, in order to understand the necessities of each of the members. 

I am also learned how to use several software platforms and scripting languages, like BrainVoyager QX and Presentation.', 'title': 'Research Intern', 'employment_type': None}]}, {'company': {'id': 32489, 'name': 'University of Naples Federico II', 'logo': 'https://media.licdn.com/dms/image/C560BAQEEY5-j17NTnA/company-logo_400_400/0/1519855915312?e=1700697600&v=beta&t=rTmgFuXR_k25UgjaSZcBRAE2fqa9xdd7-RbJkRrotYU', 'url': 'https://www.linkedin.com/company/university-of-naples-federico-ii/', 'employees': {'start': 5001, 'end': 10000}}, 'date': {'start': {'month': 4, 'day': None, 'year': 2011}, 'end': {'month': 7, 'day': None, 'year': 2011}}, 'profile_positions': [{'location': 'Naples Area, Italy', 'date': {'start': {'month': 4, 'day': None, 'year': 2011}, 'end': {'month': 7, 'day': None, 'year': 2011}}, 'company': 'University of Naples Federico II', 'description': 'Wide-band spectroscopy of ferrofluid (magnetic nanoparticles in diluted aqueous solution) for biomedical applications (medical imaging, hyperthermia for cancer treatment, drug delivery). 

Key skills: MATLAB programming, experiment design, self-management, microwave physics, nanotechnology

I did an internship at university, for the DIBET department. My supervisor was Ovidio Mario Bucci and the co-supervisor was Gennaro Bellizzi.
 
The work was about finding a new way to measure the magnetic permeability that could work on the ferrofluids that the researchers of the department used for biomedical applications. These ferrofluids have a really low concentration of magnetic nanoparticles and are water-based: this particular setting leads to many problems in this kind of measure.

I run the experiments, analyzed the data, and optimized the MATLAB code in order to shorten sensibly the time needed for the measures and analyses. 
 
We measured the magnetic permeability of aqueous ferrofluids with a concentration thirteen times lower than the lowest measured in literature, using an innovative technique we developed in the department.

The work was published in an article: "A Novel Measurement Technique for the Broadband Characterization of Diluted Water Ferrofluids for Biomedical Applications"​, on IEEE transactions on Magnetics.', 'title': 'Research Intern', 'employment_type': None}]}]
